moves.1. e4 c6 2. Bc4 d5 3. exd5 cxd5 4. Be2: Be2 struck me as passive, but there is nothing passive about White's play in a minute.
moves.4... Nf6 5. d3 Bf5 6. g4: Be2 was apparently preparation for this.  White quickly gets the initiative.
moves.6... Bd7 7. g5 Ng8: White has the advantage here with more space.
moves.11. d4 O-O-O: Now White has a dilemma.  It's difficult to castle Kingside with the pawns advanced so far.  With Black castling on the Queenside, White would like to launch a pawn advance there, but that would expose the King even further.
moves.12. h3 f6 13. Nf3 e5: Black fights back for a share of the center.
moves.14. fxe5 fxe5 15. Nc2 e4: Black creates a passed pawn.  It won't be easy to hang on to, but it will be a problem for White.
moves.16. Ng1 Qg3+: Maybe White missed this check.  With the King stuck in the middle of the board, Black can snatch a pawn.
moves.17. Kd2 Qxg5+ 18. Ne3 Bd6: Now Black may have a slight pull, but Black's K is also fairly exposed.  Black needs to complete development quickly.
moves.19. Bg4 Nh6 20. h4 Qg6 21. h5 Qf7 22. Bx: This position strikes me as chaotic with no strong advantage to either player.
moves.25... Nf5 26. Bf4 h6 27. Qg4 Kd8: Black has to make sure the Rook isn't pinned.
moves.28. Raf1 Rf8 29. Rf2 e3: White cannot play Bxe3 because of Nxe3+, forking the K and Q.
moves.30. Rf3: The position of White's K and R allows a tactic with the Ns.
moves.30... Ncxd4+ 31. cxd4 Nxd4+ 32. Kb1 Nxf3: Now the position is unbalanced.  Black has two central passed pawns, but Black has two minor pieces for a R.
moves.34. Rf1 Ke8: Black's K was vulnerable to a check from the B while sitting on a dark square.
moves.35. Qe4+ Qe7 36. Qd3 Qe6: Black starts to make threats that are not easy to meet.
moves.37. Qg6+ Qxg6+ 38. hxg6: Exchanging Qs makes the two passed pawns more powerful.
moves.40. Rg1 Rh5: White's N has nowhere to go!
moves.41. Bxh6 Rxh6: Black now has a very good game, with a material advantage and the passed pawns.
moves.42. Rg3 Rhxg6 43. Rxg6 Rxg6 44. Nf4 Rd6: Black tries to keep K and R on different color squares to avoid a simple fork.  White's K has to stay home to prevent the pawns from running to the endzone.
Now Black can force an exchange on very favorable terms.
moves.52... d3+ 53. Nxd3 Rxd3 54. Kxd3 Kf2: With Kf2, Black takes control of the promotion squares of both passed pawns.  White cannot stop the two potential Qs and resigned here.
